Thorny-Abbey, or The London-Maid; a tragedy, by T.W.: The Marriage-Broker, or The Pander; a Comedy, by M.W.M.A.: Grim the Collier of Croydon, or The Devil and his Dame; with the Devil and St. Dunstan: a Comedy, by I.T.: Never before published: but now printed at the request of sundry ingenious friends London Printed by R.D. (etc.) 1662 (14), 57 p. Preliminaries and introductory matter omitted. The following plays have been taken from this source: Anon.: Thorny-Abbey, or The London-Maid; a Tragedy Anon.: The Marriage-Broker, or The Pander; a Comedy Haughton, William: Grim the Collier of Croydon; or, The Devil and his Dame; with The Devil and Saint Dunstan: a Comedy Commendatory poems included with Thorny-Abbey. Play details Grim the collier of Croyden. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1662. Date first performed: 1593-1601 ?

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. St Dunston; Abbot of Glassenbery Morgan; Earl of London Lacy; Earl of Kent Honorea; Morgan's Daughter Marian Nan Musgrave Captain Clinton Miles Forrest Ralph Harvie Grim Parton Short-hose Clark; a Miller Joan Pluto Minos Aeacus Rhadamantus Belphagor Ackercock; or Robin Goodfellow Malbecco
Multiple speakers

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

front.head: GRIM The Collier of Croyden; OR, The Devil and his Dame: WITH The Devil and Saint Dunston. St. Dunston, Abbot of Glassenbury. Morgan, Earl of London. Lacy, Earl of Kent. Honorea, Morgan's Daughter. Marian, her Waiting maid. Nan, Marian's Maid. Musgrave, a young Gentleman. Captain Clinton. Miles Forrest, a Gentleman. Ralph Harvie, an Apothecary. Grim, the Collier of Croyden. Parson Short-hose. Clack, a Miller. Joan, a Country Maid. Pluto Devil. Minos. Devil. Æacus. Devil. Rhadamantus. Devil. Belphagor. Devil. Akercock, or Robin Good-fellow. Devil. Malbecco his Ghost-Officers, Attendants, &c.;The Stage is England.

div2.head: Scæna prima.
div2.stage: A place being provided for the Devils Consistory, enter St. Dunstan with his Beads, Book, and Crosier staff, etcetera;

sp.speaker: S. Dunst.
sp.l: Envy that always waits on Virtue's train,
And tears the Graves of quiet sleeping Souls,
Hath brought me, after many hundred years,
To show myself again upon the earth.
Know then (who list) that I am English born,
My name is Dunston; whilst I lived with men,
Chief Primate of the Holy English Church:
I was begotten in West Saxony:
My Fathers name was Heorston, my Mothers Conferred.
Endowed with my Merit's legacy,
I flourished in the reign of Seven great Kings;
The first was Adelstane, whose Niece Elflida
Malicious tongues reported, I defiled:
Next him came Edmond, then Edred, and Edwin:
And after him reigned Edgar, a great Prince,
But full of many Crimes which I restrained:
Edward his Son, and lastly Egelred.
With all these Kings was I in high esteem,
And kept both them, and all the Land in awe;
And, had I lived, the Danes had never boasted
Their then beginning Conquest of this Land;
Yet some accuse me for a Conjurer,
By reason of those many miracles
Which Heaven for holy life endowed me with.
But whoso looks into the golden Legend,
(That sacred Register of holy Saints)
Shall find me by the Pope canonised,
And happily the cause of this Report
Might rise by reason of a Vision,
Which I beheld in great King Edgar's days,
Being that time Abbot of Glassenbury,
Which (for it was a matter of some worth)
I did make known to few, until this day:
But now I purpose that the World shall see
How much those Slanderers have wronged me;
Nor will I trouble you with Courts and Kings,
Or drive a feigned Battle out of breath;
Or keep a coil myself upon the Stage;
But think you see me in my secret Cell,
Armed with my Portass, bidding of my Beads.
But on a sudden I am overcome with sleep!
If aught ensue, watch you, for Dunston dreams.

div2.stage: He layeth him down to sleep; Lightning and Thunder; the Curtains drawn, on a sudden Pluto, Minos, Aeacus, Rhadamantus set in Counsell, before them Malbecco his Ghost guarded with Furies.

sp.speaker: Pluto.
sp.l: You ever-dreaded Judges of black Hell,
Grim Minos, Aeacus, and Rhadamant,
Lords of Cocitus, Styx, and Phlegiton,
Prince, of Darkness, Pluto's Ministers,
Know that the greatness of his present Cause
Hath made ourself in person set as judge,
To hear the arraignment of Malbecco's Ghost;
Stand forth thou ghastly pattern of Despair,
And to this powerful Synod tell thy tail,
That we may hear if thou canst justly say
Thou wert not Author of thy own decay.

sp.speaker: Malb.
sp.l: Infernal Jove, great Prince of Tartary,
With humble reverence poor Malbecco speaks
Still trembling with the fatal memory
Of his so late concluded Tragedy.
I was (with thanks to your great bounty) bred
A wealthy Lord, whilst that I lived on Earth;
And so might have continued to this day,
Had not that plague of mankind fallen on me:
For I (poor man) joined woe unto my name,
By choosing out a Woman for my Wife.
A Wife! a curse ordained for the World.
Fair Hellena! fair she was indeed,
But foully stained with inward wickedness.
I kept her bravely, and I loved her dear;
But that dear love did cost my Life, and all.
To reckon up a thousand of her pranks,
Her pride, her wasteful spending, her unkindness,
Her false dissembling, seeming sanctity,
Her scolding, pouting, prating, meddling,
And twenty hundred more of the same stamp,
Were but to reap an endless Catalogue
Of what the World is plagued with every day.
But for the main of that I have to tell,
It chanced thus: Late in a rainy night
A crew of Gallants came unto my House,
And (Will I, Nill I) would forsooth be lodged;
I brought them in, and made them all good cheer,
(Such as I had in store) and lodged them soft:
Amongst them one, yclept Paridell,
(The falsest Thief that ever trod on ground)
Robbed me, and with him stole away my Wife.
I (for I loved her dear) pursued the Thief.
And, after many days in travel spent,
Found her amongst a crew of Satyrs wild,
Kissing, and colling all the live-long night:
I spake her fair, and prayed her to return:
But she in scorn commands me to be gone;
And glad I was to fly, to save my life,
But when I backward came unto my House,
I find it spoiled and all my treasure gone.
Desperate and mad, I ran I knew not whither,
Calling and crying out on Heaven and Fate,
Till seeing none to pity my distress.
I threw myself down headlong on a Rock,
And so concluded all my ills at once.
Now, judge you, Justice Benchers, if my Wife
Were not the instrument to end my life.

sp.speaker: Pluto.
sp.l: Can it be possible (you Lords of Hell)
Malbecco's tale of Women should be true;
Is Marriage now become so great a Curse,
That Whilom was the comfort of the World?

sp.speaker: Minos.
sp.l: Women, it seems, have lost their native shame,
As no man better may complain than I,
Though not of any whom I made my Wife,
But of my Daughter who procured my fall.

sp.speaker: Aeacus.
sp.l: It is strange what Plaints are brought us every day
Of men made miserable by marriage;
So that amongst a thousand, scarcely ten
Have not some grievous actions against their Wives.

sp.speaker: Rhad.
sp.l: My Lord, if Rhadamant might counsel you,
Your Grace should send someone into the World,
That might make proof if it be true or no.

sp.speaker: Pluto.
sp.l: And wisely hast thou counselled Rhadamant,
Call in Belphagor to me presently.
sp.stage: One of the Furies goes for Belphagor.
sp.l: He is the fittest that I know in Hell
To undertake a task of such import,
For he is patient, mild, and pitiful:
Humours but ill agrees with our Kingdom.
And here he comes; Belphagor, so it is,
We in our awful Synod have decreed.
(Upon occasions to ourselves best known)
That thou from hence shall go into the world,
And take upon thee the shape of a man;
In which estate thou shalt be married:
Choose thee a Wife that best may please thyself,
And live with her a twelvemonth and a day;
Thou shalt be subject unto human chance
So far as common wit cannot relieve thee;
Thou shalt of us receive ten thousand pounds,
Sufficient stock to use for thy increase:
But whatsoever happens in that time,
Look not from us for succour or relief;
This shalt thou do, and when the time is expired,
Bring word to us what thou hast seen and done.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: With all my heart (my Lord) I am content,
So I may have my Servant Akercock
To wait upon me as if he were my man,
That he may witness likewise what is done.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: We are contented, he shall go with thee

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: But what meantime decrees your Majesty of poor Malbecco?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: He shall rest with us
Until Belphagor do return again,
And as he finds so will we give his doom.
Come let us go and set our Spial forth,
Who for a time must make experiment,
If Hell be not on Earth, as well as here.

div2.stage: It thunders and lightens; the Devils go forth; Dunston rising, runneth about the Stage, laying about him with his Staff.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.l: Sathan avaunt, thou art man's enemy,
Thou shalt not live amongst us so unseen,
So to betray us to the Prince of Darkness:
Sathan avaunt, I do conjure thee hence.
What dreamest thou Dunston? yea I dreamt indeed,
Must then the Devil come into the world?
Such is belike the infernal Kings decree;
Well, be it so, for Dunston is content,
Mark well the process of the Devil's disguise,
Who happily may learn you to be wise.
Women beware, and make your bargains well,
The Devil, to choose a Wife, is come from hell.

div2.head: SCENE 2d.
div2.stage: Enter Morgan Earl of London, Lacy Earl of Kent, with Miles Forrest.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: My Lord of Kent, your Honour knows my mind,
That ever have, and still do honour you,
Accounting it my Daughter's happiness,
(Amidst her other infelicities)
That you vouchsafe to love her as you do:
How gladly I would grant your Lordships suite,
The Heavens can witness, which with ruthless ears
Have often heard my yet unpitied Plaints;
And could I find some means for her recovery,
None but yourself should have her to your Wife,

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: My Lord of London, now long time it is
Since Lacy first was suitor to your Daughter,
The fairest Honorea, in whose eyes
Honour itself in Love's sweet bosom lies:
What shall we say, or seem to strive with heaven,
Who speechless sent her first into the world;
In vain it is for us to think to loose
That which by Natures self we see is bound:
Her beauty, with her other virtues joined,
Are gifts sufficient, though she want a tongue;
And some will count it Virtue in a woman
Still to be bound to un-offending Silence;
Though I could wish with half of all my Lands,
That she could speak: but since it may not be,
It were vain to imprison Beauty with her speech.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Have you not heard (my Lords) the wondrous fame.
Of holy Dunston, Abbot of Glassenbury,
What miracles he hath achieved of late,
And how the rood of Dovercott did speak,
Confirming his opinion to be true,
And how the holy Consistory fell.
With all the Monks that were assembled there,
Saving one beam, whereon this Dunston sate,
And other more such miracles as these.
They say he is of such religious life,
That Angels often use to talk with him,
And tell to him the secrets of the Heavens.
No question, if your Honours would but try,
He could procure my Lady for to speak.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Believe me Forrest, thou hast well advised,
For I have heard of late much talk of him.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Is not that Dunston he, who checked the King
About his privy dealing with the Nun,
And made him to do penance for the fault?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: The same is he, for whom I straight will send
Miles Forrest shall in post to Glassenbury,
And gently, pray the Abbot for my sake
To come to London: sure I hope the Heavens
Have ordained Dunston to do Morgan good.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Let us dispatch him thither presently,
For I myself will stay for his return.
And see some end or other ere I go.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Come then Lord Lacy, Forrest come away.

div2.head: SCENE 3d.
div2.stage: Enter Belphagor attired like a Physician; Akercock his man in a Tawny Coat.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now is Belphagor an incarnate Devil
Come to the earth to seek him out a Dame:
Hell be my speed, and so I hope it will.
In lovely London are we here arrived
Whereas I hear the Earl hath a fair Daughter
So full of virtue, and soft modesty,
That yet she never gave a man foul word.

sp.speaker: Ak.
sp.l: Marry indeed they say she cannot speak.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: For this cause have I taken this disguise.
And will profess me a Physician,
Come upon purpose for to cure the Lady;
Marry no way shall bind me but herself,
And she I do intend shall be my wife.

sp.speaker: Ak.
sp.l: But Master, tell me one thing by the way,
Do you not mean that I shall marry too?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No Akercock, thou shalt be still unwed,
For if they be as bad as is reported,
One wife will be enough to tire us both.

sp.speaker: Ak.
sp.l: O then you mean that I shall now and then,
Have, as it were a course at base with her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nor so, nor so, that is one of Marriage plagues,
Which I must seek to shun amongst the rest,
And live in sweet contentment with my wife,
That when I back again return to hell
All women may be bound to reverence me,
For saving of their Credits as I will.
But who comes here?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: This needs must tickle Musgrave to the quick,
And stretch his heart-strings farther by an inch,
That Lacy must be married to his Love;
And by that Match my market is near marred,
For Mariana, whom I most affect;
But I must cast about by some devise
To help myself and to prevent the Earl.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: This Fellow fitly comes to meet with me,
Who seems to be acquainted with the Earl;
Good Fortune guide you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: As much to you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Might I entreat a favour at your hands?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am a stranger here in England, Sir,
Brought from my native home upon report,
That the Earl's Daughter wants the use of speech,
I have been practised in such Cures ere now,
And willingly would try my skill on her:
Let me request you so to favour me,
As to direct me to her Father's house.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: With all my heart, and welcome shall you be
To that good Earl, who mourns his Daughter's want;
But they have for a holy Abbot sent,
Who can (men say) do many miracles,
In hope that he will work this wondrous cure.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Whatever he be, I know it is past his skill,
Nor any in the world, besides myself,
Did ever sound the depth of that devise.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Musgrave well met; I needs must speak with you.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: I came to seek you.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Tarry you a while.
Shall I entreat you sir to walk before
With this same Gentleman, and overtake you.
This is the news, the Earl of Kent is come,
And in all haste the marriage must be made,
Your Lady weeps, and knows not what to do,
But hopes that you will work some means or other
To stop the cross proceedings of the Earl.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: Alas poor Clinton, what can Musgrave do?
Unless I should by stealth convey her thence,
On which a thousand dangers do depend.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Well (to be brief because I cannot stay)
Thus stands the case, if you will promise me,
To work your Cousin Marian to be mine;
I will so devise that you shall purchase her,
And therefore tell me if you like the match?

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: With all my heart Sir, yea and thank you too.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Then say no more but leave the rest to me,
For I have plotted how it shall be done;
I must go follow yon fair Gentleman,
On whom I build my hopes. Musgrave adieu.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: Clinton farewell, I will wish thee good success.

div2.head: SCENE IV.
div2.stage: Enter Morgan, Lacy, Dunston, Forrest, Honorea, Marian.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Thou holy man, to whom the higher Powers.
Have given the gift of Cures beyond conceit;
Welcome thou art unto Earl Morgans house!
The house of sorrow yet, unless by thee
Our joys may spring anew, which if they do,
Reward and praise shall both attend on thee.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: And we will ever reverence thy name,
Making the Chronicles to speak thy praise;
So Honorea may but have her speech.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.l: My Lords, you know the hallowed gifts of Tongues,
Comes from the self-same power that gives us breath,
He binds and looseth them at his dispose,
And in his name will Dunston undertake
To work this cure upon fair Honorea,
Hang there my Harp, my solitary muse,
Companion of my Contemplation.
sp.stage: He hangs his Harp on the wall.
sp.l: And, Lady, kneel with me upon the earth,
That both our Prayers may ascend to Heaven.

div2.stage: They kneel down; then enters Clinton, with Belphagor, terming himself Castiliano, and Akercock as Robin Goodfellow.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: So shall you do the Lady a good turn,
And bind both him and me to you forever.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I have determined what I mean to do.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Here be the Earls, and with them is the Fryer,

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What is he praying?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: So methinks he is;
But I will disturb him by your leave my Lords,
Here is a Stranger from beyond the Seas
Will undertake to cure your Lordships daughter.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: The holy Abbot is about the Cure.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yea, but my Lord he will never finish it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: How canst thou tell, what Country-man

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am by birth, my Lord, a Spaniard born,
And by descent came of a Noble house,
Though for the love I bare to secret Arts,
I never cared to seek for vain Estate,
Yet by my skill I have increased my wealth:
My name Castiliano, and my birth
No baser than the best blood of Castecle.
Hearing your Daughter's strange infirmity,
Joined with such matchless beauty and rare virtue,
I crossed the Seas on purpose for her good

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.l: Fond man presuming on thy weaker skill,
That thinkest by Art to over-rule the Heavens:
Thou knowest not what it is thou undertakest.
No, no, my Lord, your daughter must be cured
By fasting, prayer, and religious works;
Myself for her will sing a solemn mass,
And give her three sips of the holy Chalice,
And turn my Beads with Aves and with Creeds,
And thus, my Lord, your Daughter must be helped.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: 'Swounds, what a prating keeps the bald-pate Fryer?
My Lord, my Lord, here is Church work for an age!
Tush, I will cure her in a minutes space,
That she shall speak as plain as you or I.

div2.stage: Dunston's Harp sounds on the wall.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Hark, hark my Lord, the holy Abbot's Harp
Sounds by itself so hanging on the wall!

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.l: Unhallowed man, that scornest the sacred read.
Hark how the testimony of my truth
Sounds heavenly music with an Angel's hand,
To testify Dunston's integrity,
And prove thy active boast of no effect.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Tush Sir, that music was to welcome me;
The Harp hath got another Master now,
I warrant you it will never tune you more.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.l: Who should be Master of my Harp but I?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Try then what service I will do for you.

div2.stage: He tryes to play, but cannot.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.l: Thou art some Sorcerer, or Nigromancer.
Who by thy Spells dost hold these holy strings.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Cannot your Holiness unbind the bonds?
Then I perceive my skill is most of force;
You see, my Lord, the Abbot is but weak,
I am the man must do your Daughter good.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: What wilt thou ask for to work thy cure?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: That without which I will not do the Cure;
Herself to be my Wife, for which intent
I came from Spain: then if she shall be mine,
Say so, or keep her else forever dumb.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: The Earl of Kent, mine honourable friend,
Hath to my Daughter been a Suitor long,
And much it would displease both her and him
To be prevented of their wished love;
Ask what thou wilt beside, and I will grant it.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, what should the crazy Earl
Do with so young a Virgin as your Daughter?
I dare stand to her choice twixt him and me.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: And I will pawn mine Earldom with my Love,
And loose them both, if I loose Honorea.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: A match my Lords, we will stand unto the Choice.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I am contented, if the Earl be pleased.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: I were not worthy of her did I doubt.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Then there it goes, fetch me a bowl of Wine,
This is the match my Lord, before I work,
If she refuse the Earl, she must be mine.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: It is

div2.stage: One brings him a Cup of Wine, he straynes the juyce of the Herb into it.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Now shall your Lordships see a Spaniard's skill.
Who from the plains of new America
Can find out sacred Simples of esteem
To bind, and unbind Nature's strongest Powers:
This Herb, which mortal men have seldom found,
Can I with ease procure me when I list;
And by this juice shall Honorea speak;
Here Lady, drink the freedom of thy heart,
And may it teach thee long to call me Love.
Now lovely Honorea thou art free,
Let thy Celestial voice make choice of me.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Base Alien, mercenary Fugitive,
Presumptuous Spaniard, that with shameless pride
Darest ask an English Lady for thy Wife.
I scorn, my Slave should honour thee so much,
And for myself, I like myself the worse,
That thou darest hope the gaining of my Love.
Go, get thee gone, the shame of my esteem,
And seek some drudge that may be like thyself.
But as for you, good Earl of Kent,
Methinks your Lordship being of these years
Should be past dreaming of a second Wife.
Fie, fie, fie, my Lord, it is lust in doting age;
I will not patronise so foul a sin.
An old man dote on youth! it is monstrous;
Go, home go home, and rest your weary head,
It were pity such a brow should learn to bud.
And lastly unto you my Lord, and Father,
Your love to me is too much overseen,
That in your care and counsel should devise,
To tie your Daughter's choice to two such Grooms.
You may elect for me, but I will dispose
And fit myself far better than both those;
And so I will conclude, you as you please.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Call you this making of a Woman speak?
I think they all wish she were dumb again.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: How now my Lord, what are you in a muse?

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: I would to God her Tongue were tied again.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Aye marry Sir, but that is another thing,
The Devil cannot tie a woman's tongue,
I would the Fryer could do that with his Beads.
But it is no matter, you my Lord have promised,
If she refuse the Earl, she should be mine.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Win her, and wear her man with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O! I will haunt her till I make her stoop,
Come, come my Lord, This was to try her voice,
Let us in and court her; one of us shall speed.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Happy man be his dole that misseth her, say I,

sp.speaker: Dunst.
sp.l: My weaker Senses cannot apprehend
The means this Stranger used to make her speak;
There is some secret mystery therein,
Concealed from Dunston! which the Heavens reveal,
That I may scourge this bold blaspheming man,
Who holds religious works of little worth.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Now Captain Clinton what think you of me?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Mythinks, as yet, the Jest holds pretty
The one hath taught her to deny himself,
The other wooed so long he cannot speed.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: This News will please young Musgrave.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Marry will it,
And I will hasten to acquaint him with them,
Come let us away.

div2.stage: Enter Parson Shorthouse, and Grim the Collier.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: No, Master. Parson, grief hath made my heart and me a pair of Balance, as heavy as lead; every night I dream I am a town top, and that I am whipped up and down with the scourge-stick of Love, and the metal of Affection; and when I work, I find myself stark naked and as cold as a stone: now judge how I am tumbled and tossed; poor Grim the Collier hath wished himself burnt up amongst his Coals.

sp.speaker: Par. shorth.
sp.l: O Grim be wise dream not of Love
Thy sorrows cannot Fancy move,
If Jug love thee, love her again;
If not thy kindness then refrain.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I am not skilled in your rhyming Master. Parson; but that which is bred in the Flesh will never out of the Bone; I have seen as much as another man, my travel should teach me there is never a day in the week but I carry Coals from Croydon to London; and now when I rise in the morning to harness my Horses, and load my Cart, methinks I have a Tailor sowing stitches in my Heart; when I am driving my Cart, my Heart that wanders one way my Eyes they leer another, my Feet they lead me I know not whither, but now and then into a Slow over head and ears; so that poor Grim that before was over-shoes in Love, is now over head and ears in Dirt and Mire.

sp.speaker: Par. Shor.
sp.l: Well Grim my counsel shall suffice
To help thee, but in any wise
Be ruled by me, and thou shall see,
As thou lovest her, she shall love thee.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: A-lard! but do you think that will be so, I should laugh till I tickle to see that day, and forswear sleep all the next night after; O Master Parson, I am so haltered in affection, that I may tell you in secret, here is nobody else hears me, I take no care how I fill my Sacks; every time I come to London my Coals are found faulty; I have been five times pilfered, my Coals given to the Poor, and my Sacks burnt before my face. It were a shame to speak this, but Truth will come to light; O Ione! thou hast thrown the Cole-dust of thy love into my eyes and stricken me quite blind.

sp.speaker: Par. shorth.
sp.l: Now afore God the Collier chooseth well;
For beauty, Jug, doth bear away the bell:
And I love her; then Collier thou must miss,
For Parson Shorthose vows, Jug shall be his.
But hearest thou Grim, I have that in my head,
To plot that how thou shalt the Maiden wed.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: But are you sure you have that in your head? O for a hammer to knock that out; one blow at your Pate would lay all open to me, and make me as wise as you.

sp.speaker: Shorth.
sp.l: Thinkst thou I do so often look
For nothing on my learned book,
As that I cannot work the feat;
I warrant I will the Miller cheat,
And make Jug thine, in spite of him;
Will this content thee neighbour Grim.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Content me! Aye and so highly, that if you do this feat for me, you hire me to you as one hireth an Ox or an Ass to use to ride, to spur, or anything; yours to demand, miserable Grim! Ione's Handmaid for so I have called myself ever since last May day, when she gave me her hand to kiss.

sp.speaker: Shorth.
sp.l: Well, let us away, and in all haste,
About it ere the day be past;
And ever after, if thou hast her,
Acknowledge me to be thy Master.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I woose Sir; Come let us away, the best drink in Croydon's yours, I have it for you, even a dozen of Jugs to Jug's health.

div2.stage: Enter Earl Morgan, Earl Lacy, Mariana.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: My Lord of Kent, the latter motion
Doth bind me to you in a higher degree,
Than all those many favours gone before;
And now the issue of my help relies
Only on Mariana's gentleness,
Who, if she will in such a common good
Put to her helping hand the Match is made.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: You need not make a doubt of Marian,
Whose love unto her Lady were enough;
Besides her Cozens and her own consent,
To move her to a greater thing than this.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: My Lords, if aught there be in Marian,
That may or pleasure you, or profit her,
Ye shall not need to doubt of my consent.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Gramercy Marian, and indeed the thing
Is, in itself, a matter of no moment:
If it be weighed aright; and therefore this,
Thou knowest the bargain twixt me and the Doctor,
Concerning Marriage with my only Daughter,
Whom I determined that my Lord of Kent
Should have espoused; but I see her mind
Is only set upon thy Cousin Musgrave,
And in her Marriage to use constraint
Were bootless; therefore thus we have devised,
Lord Lacy is content to loose his part,
And to resign his Title to young Musgrave.
But now the Doctor will not yield his right;
Thus we determine to begin his hopes:
Thou shalt this night be brought unto his bed,
Instead of her, and he shall marry thee,
Musgrave shall have my Daughter, She her will,
And so shall all things sort to our content.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: And this thou shalt be sure of Marian,
The Doctor's wealth will keep thee royally;
Besides, thou shalt be ever near thy Friends,
That will not see thee wronged by any man.
Say then wilt thou resolve to marry him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My Lords, you know I am but young,
The Doctor is fit for one of riper years,
Yet in regard of Honorea's good,
My Cousin's profit, and all your contents,
I yield myself to be the Doctor's wife.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: It is kindly spoken, gentle Marian,
But here the Doctor comes.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Then I will away,
Lest he suspect aught by my being here.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: Do, and let me alone to close with him.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: May he never speak that makes a Woman speak,
She talks now, sure for all the time that is past,
Her Tongue is like a Scare-crow in a tree,
That clatters still with every puff of wind;
I have so haunted her from place to place,
About the hall from thence into the parlour,
Up to the Chamber, down into the Garden.
And still she rails, and chafes, and scolds,
As if it were the Sessions day in hell,
Yet will I haunt her with an open mouth.
And never leave her till I force her love me.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: Now, Master Doctor, what a match or no.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: A match, quoth you, I think the Devil himself
Cannot match her, for if he could, I should.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: Well, be content, it is I must work the mean,
To make her yield whether she will or no:
My Lord of Kent is gone hence in a chafe,
And now I purpose that she shall be yours,
Yet to herself unknown, for she shall think
That Musgrave is the man, but it shall be you;
Seem you still discontented and no more:
Go Mariana call thy Mistress hither,
Now when she comes, dissemble what you know,
And go away, as if you cared not for her,
So will she be the sooner brought unto it.

sp.speaker: Castil.
sp.l: My Lord, I thank you for your honest care,
And, as I may, will study to requite it.
But here your Daughter comes: No, no, my Lord.
It is not for favour I regard nor her,
Your Promise it is I challenge, which I will have;
It was my Bargain No man else should have her,
Not that I love her, but I will not bewronged
By anyone, my Lord, and so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: He is passing cunning to deceive himself,
But all the better for the after sport.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Sir did you send for me.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: Honorea, for thee.
And this it is, however unearthly
I have bestowed my love so long upon thee,
That wilt so manifestly contradict me;
Yet, that thou mayst perceive how I esteem thee,
I make thyself the Guardian of thy Love,
That thine own fancy may make choice for thee;
I have persuaded with my Lord of Kent,
To leave to love thee. Now the peevish Doctor
Swears, that his interest he will never resign;
Therefore we must by Policy deceive him,
He shall suppose he lieth this night with thee,
But Mariana shall supply thy room,
And thou with Musgrave in another Chamber,
Shall secretly be lodged; when this is done,
It will be too late to call that back again,
So shalt thou have thy mind, and he a wife.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: But wilt thou, Mariana yield to this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For your sake, Lady I will undertake it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Gramercy Marian, and my noble Father.
Now I acknowledge that indeed you love me.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: Well, no more words, but be you both prepared,
The night draweth on, and I have sent in secret
For Musgrave, that he may be brought unseen,
To hide Suspicion from their jealous eyes.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I warrant you, come Marian, let us go.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: And then, my Lord of Kent, shall be my Son,
Should I go wed my Daughter to a Boy?
No, no, young Girls must have their Wills restrained,
For if the Rule be theirs, all runs to naught.

div2.stage: Enter Clack the Miller, with Ione.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.p: Be not Jug, as a man would say, finer than Five pence, or that it you are more proud than a Peacock that is, to seem to scorn to call in at Clacks mill as you pass over the bridge, there be as good Wenches as you be glad to pay me toll.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.p:
Like enough Clack I had as live they as I, and a great deal rather too; you that take toll of so many Maids, shall never toll me after you: O God, what a dangerous thing it is but to peep once into Love! I was never so haunted with
my harvest-work as I am with Love's passions.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.p: Aye but Ione, bear old Proverbs in your memory, soft and fair; now sir, if you make too much haste to fall foul, aye and that upon a foul one too, there fades the flower of all Croydon, tell me but this, is not Clack the Miller as good a name as Grim the Collier?

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Alas, I know no difference in names;
To make a Maid, or choose, or to refuse.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.p: You were best to say, No, nor in men another. Well, I will be sworn I have; but I have no reason to tell you so much, that care so little for me; yet hark:

div2.stage: Clack speaketh in her ear: enter Grim, Parson Shorthose.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: O Master. Parson, there he stands like a Scare-crow to drive me away from her, that sticks as close to my heart, as my shirt to my back, or my hose to my heel; O Master. Parson Shorthose, Grim is but a man as another man is, Colliers have but lives as other men have; all is gone, if she go from me, Grim is nobody without her, my heart is in my mouth, my mouth is in my hand, my hand threatens vengeance against the Miller, as it were a Beadle with a whip in his hand, triumphing over a Beggar's back.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Be silent Grim, stand close and see,
So shall we know how all things be.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: In wisdom I am appeased, but in anger
I broil as it were a rasher upon the coals.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: I will not despise the Trades ye either have,
Yet Grim the Collier may, if he be wise,
Live even as merry as the day is long;
For, in my judgment, in his mean estate
Consists as much content, as in more wealth.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: O Master. Parson, write down this sweet saying of her in Grim's commendations; she hath made my heart leap like a hobby horse; O Ione this speech of thine will I carry with me even to my grave.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Be silent then.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.p: Well, then I perceive you mean to lead your life in a Coalpit, like one of the Devil's drudges, and have your face look like the outside of an old iron pot, or a blacking box.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: He calleth my Trade into question, I cannot forbear him.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Nay then you spoil all neighbour Grim, I warrant you she will answer him.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: What I intend I am not bound to show
To thee, nor any other but my Mother,
To whom in duty I submit myself;
Yet this I tell thee, though my birth be mean,
My honest virtuous life shall help to mend it,
And if I marry any in all this life,
He shall say boldly he hath an honest wife.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p:
O that it were my fortune to light upon her, on that Condition my Horses were dead, and my Cart broken, and I bound to carry Coals as long as I live from Croydon to London on my bare shoulders; Master. Parson the Flesh is frail, he shall tempt her no longer; she is but weak, and he is the stronger; I will upon him. Miller thou art my neighbour, and therein charity hold my hands; but methinks you having a water-gap of your own, you may do as other Millers do, grind your grist at home, knock your cogs into your own Mill, you shall not cog with her she doth descry thee, and I defy thee to a mortal
fight, and so, Miller, good night. And now sweet Ione, be it openly known thou art my own.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.l: Well Grim, since thou art so Collier-like choleric.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Miller, I will not be mealy mouthed.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.p: I will give thee the fewer words now, be cause the next time we meet I will pay thee all in dry blows, carry Coals at a Collier's hands! and I do let my Mill be drowned up in water, and I hanged in the roof.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: And if thou lovest me Grim, forbear him now.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: If I love thee! dost thou doubt of that? nay rip me up, and look into my heart, and thou shalt see thy own face pictured there as plainly as in the proudest Looking glass in all Croydon; if I love thee! then tears gush out, and show my love.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.p: What Master. Parson are you there? you remember you promised to win Ione for my own wearing?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I warrant thee Clack; but now be gone,
Leave me to work that here alone.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.l: Well, farewell Master. Shorthose, be true when you are trusted,

sp.speaker: Short,
sp.l: She shall be neither his nor thine,
For I intend to make her mine,

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: If I love thee Ione; those very words are a purgation to me, you shall see desperation in my face, and death marching in my very countenance; if I love!

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: What Grim hath grief drowned thee at last?
Are all thy joys overcast?
Is Ione in place, and thou so sad,
Her presence, man, should make thee glad.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Good Master Parson, it were no fault of mine,
He takes occasion where there none was given;
I will not blab unto the World, my love
I owe to him, and shall do whilst I live.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Well Ione, without all Ifs or Ands, E-persese, A-persese, or Tittle-tattles in the world, I do love thee, and so much, that in thy absence I cry when I see thee, and rejoice with my very heart when I cannot behold thee.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: No doubt, no doubt thou lovest her well.
But listen now to what I tell;
Since ye are both so well agreed,
I wish you make more haste and speed,
Tomorrow is Holy-rood day,
When all a-nutting take their way,
Within the Wood a Close doth stand,
Encompassed round on either hand,
With Trees and Bushes, there will I
Dispatch your marriage presently.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: O Master Parson, your devising Fate hath blessed me forever; Ione we will have that so; the shorter the work, the sweeter.

sp.speaker: Iane,
sp.l: And if my Mother give but her consent,
My absence shall in no case hinder it.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: She! quoth she, she is mine already, we will to her presently. Master. Parson; it is a match; we will meet you: now Miller do I go beyond you, I have stripped him of the Wench, as a Cook would strip an Eel out of her skin, or a Pudding out of the Case thereof; now I talk of a Pudding, O it is my only food, I am old dog at it; Come Ione, let us away, I will pudding you.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Well, if my Fortune luckily ensue,
As you shall cozen him, I will cozen you.

div2.stage: Enter Castiliano at one door with Mariana, Earle Lacy, at an other door with Honorea.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Come lovely Honorea, bright as day,
As came Alomena from her sacred bed
With Jupiter, shaped like Amphitrio:
So show my Love, my Love! whom have we here?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Sweet Musgrave; out alas I am betrayed!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Thou art my Love?

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: No, mine?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Nor yours, nor yours:
But Musgrave's Love; O Musgrave where art thou?

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Be not displeased my Dear, give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: My hand, false Earl, nor hand not heart of mine;
Couldst thou thus cunningly deceive my hopes,
And could my Father give consent thereto,
Well, neither he nor thou shalt force my Love.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: It is I fair Honorea am thy Love,
Forsake the worthless Earl, give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Whose hand would you have sir? this hand is mine,
And mine is yours, then keep you to your own.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Yet are you mine, sir, and I mean to keep you;
What, do you think to shake me off so soon?
No gentle Husband, now it is too late;
You should have looked before you came to bed.

div2.stage: Enter Rob. Goodf. with his Masters Gown.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Many good morrows to my gentle Master,
And my new Mistress. God give you both joy;
What say you to your Gown sir, this cold morning?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Robin I am undone, and cast away.
How Master, cast away upon a Wife!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Yea Robin cast away upon a Wife.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Cast her away then Master; can you not?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No sir he cannot, nor he shall not do it.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why, how know you? I am sure you are not she.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes sir, I am your Mistress as it falls.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: As it falls! quoth ye, marry a foul fall is it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Base Rascal, dost thou say that I am foul?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: No, it was foul play for him to fall upon you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How know you that he fell, were you so nigh.

div2.stage: She giveth Robin a box on the eare.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Mass it should seem it was he that fell if any.
For you methinks are of a mounting natures
What, at my Ears at first! a good beginning.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: My dear Delight, why dost thou stain thy Cheeks?
Those rosie Beds with this unseemly dew;
Shake off those Tears that now untimely fall,
And smile on me, that am thy Summers joy.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Hapless am I to loose so sweet a prison,
Thus to obtain a weary liberty;
Happy had I been so to have remained,
Of which estate I never should have complained.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Whoop whoo! more Marriages! and all of a sort; happy are they, I see, that live without them; if this be the beginning, what will be the ending?

div2.stage: Enter to them Earle Morg. and Dunst.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Look Dunston where they be, displeased no doubt,
Try if thou canst work reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: My Lord, I challenge you of breach of promise,
And claim your Daughter here to be my wife.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Your claim is naught, sir, she is mine already.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Your claim is naught Sir, I am none of yours.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your claim is here Sir, Marian is yours.
What Husband, newly married, and inconstant!
Agreed we so well together all this night,
And must we now fall out? for shame, for shame.
A man of your years, and be so unstaid!
Come, come away, there may no other be,
I will have you, therefore you shall have me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: This is the bravest Country in the world,
Where men get wives whether they will or no;
I trow ere long some Wench will challenge me.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O! is not this a goodly consequence,
I must have her, because she will have me?

sp.speaker: Dunston.
sp.l: Ladies and Gentlemen, hear Dunston speak:
Marriage, no doubt, is ordained by Providence,
Is sacred, not to be, by vain affect,
Turned to the idle humours of men's brains;
Besides, for you my Lady Honorea,
Your duty binds you to obey your Father,
Who better knows what fits you than yourself;
And it were, in you, great folly to neglect
The Earl's great love, whereof you are unworthy,
Should you but seem offended with the match;
Therefore submit yourself, to make amends;
For it is your fault, so may you all be friends.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: And Daughter, you must think what I have done,
Was for your good, to wed you to the Earl,
Who will maintain and love you royally:
For what had Musgrave but his idle shape?
A shadow to the substance you must build on.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: She will build substances on him I trow,
Who keeps a Shrew against her will, had better let her go.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Madam conceal your grief, and seem content,
For, as it is, you must be ruled perforce;
Dissemble till convenient time may serve
To think on this despite and Musgrave's love.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Tell me my Dear, will thou at length be pleased.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: As good be pleased, my Lord, as not be eased;
Yet though my former love did move me much,
Think not amiss, the same love may be yours.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What! is it a Match? nay then since you agree,
I cannot mend myself, for aught I see;
And therefore, it is no good to be content
Come Lady, it is your lot to be my Dame.
Lording adieu, God send ye all good speed;
Some have their Wives for pleasure, some for need.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Adieu Castiliano we are friends?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Yes, yes, my Lord, there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: No remedy, my Masters for a Wife?
A note for young beginners, mark it well.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Now Gallants what imagine you of this,
Our noses are all flirt; for Mariana,
The Spanish Doctor hath her to his wife;
And Musgraves hopes are dead for Honorea,
For she is married to the Earl of Kent,
It will be good sport to see them when they rise,
If so they be not gotten up already?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: I say the Devil go with them all for me,
The Spanish Doctor marry Marian!
I think that Slave was born to cross me still;
Had it not been last day before the Earl,
Upon my Conscience I had cracked his Crown,
When first he asked the Lady for his Wife;
Now hath he got her too, whom I desired.
Why, he will away with her ere long to Spain,
And keep her there to dispossess our hopes.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: No, I can comfort ye for that suppose;
For yesterday he hired a dwelling house;
And here he means to tarry all this year,
So long at least, whatever he doth hereafter.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: A sudden plot-form comes into my mind,
And this it is, Miles Forrest, thou and I
Are partly well acquainted with the Doctor.
Ralph Harvey shall along with us to him,
Him we will prefer for his Apothecary:
Now, sir, when Ralph and he are once acquainted,
His wife may often come unto his House,
Either to see his Garden, or suchlike;
For doubt not Women will have means enough
If they be willing, as I hope she will;
There may we meet her, and let each one plead,
He that speeds best, why let him carry it.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: I needs must laugh, to think how all we three,
In the contriving of this feat, agree;
But having got her, every man will strive,
How each may other of her love deprive.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Tut, Forrest, Love admits these friendly strifes;
But say, How like you of my late devise?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Surpassing well, but let us about it straight,
Lest he, before our coming be provided.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: Tush Cozen, tell not me; but this devise
Was long ago concluded twixt you two,
Which divers reasons move me to imagine;
And therefore these are toys to blind my eyes,
To make me think she only loved me,
And yet is married to another man.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why Cozen Musgrave, are your eyes so blind,
You cannot see the truth of that report;
Did you not know my Lord was always bent,
Whatever came, to wed her to the Earl:
And have you not, besides, heard the devise
He used to marry her against her will,
Betrayed, poor Soul, unto Earl Lacye's bed,
She thought she held young Musgrave in her arms.
Her morning tears might testify her thoughts;
Yet thou shalt see she loves thee more than him,
And thou shalt taste the sweets of her delights;
Mean time my House shall be thy mansion,
And thy abode, for thither will she come;
Use thou that opportunity, and try
Whether she loved thee, or did but dissemble.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: If she continue kind to me hereafter
I shall imagine well of her and you.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Now Dame, in talk, what Gentleman is this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My Cozen Musgrave, Husband, comes to see you.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Musgrave! now on my Faith heartily welcome:
Give me thy hand, my Cozen, and my Friend,
My Partner in the loss of Honorea,
We two must needs be Friends, our Fortune is like:
Marry, yet I am richer by a Shrew.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: It is better be a Shrew, sir, than a Sheep;
You have no cause I hope yet to complain.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No Dame, for yet you know it is honeymoon;
What, we have scarcely settled our acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: I doubt not, Cozen, but ye shall agree;
For she is mild enough if she be pleased.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: So is the Devil, they say, yea Cozen, yea,
My Dear and I, I doubt not, shall agree.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir, here be two or three Gentlemen at the door would gladly speak a word with your Worship.
sp.l: They need no bidding methinks, they can come alone.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: God save you Seignior Castiliano.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O Captain Comesta, Welcome all my friends.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Sir, we are come to bid God give you joy,
And see your House.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Welcome Gentlemen:
It is kindly done to come to see us here.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: This kindness makes me fear my Master's head;
Such hot-spurs must have game; however they get it.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: We have a suite to you, Castiliano.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What is it, Sir, if it lies in me, it is done.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Nay, but a trifle Sir, and that is
This same young man, by trade Apothecary,
Is willing to retain unto your Cures.

sp.speaker: Castil.
sp.l: Marry with all my heart and welcome too.
What may I call your name my honest friend?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Ralph Harvey Sir, your neighbour here hard by,
The Golden Lion is my dwelling place,
Where what you please shall be with care, performed.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Gramercies Harvey; welcome all my Friends,
Let us in and hand sell our new mansion house
With a carousing round of Spanish wine.
Come Cozen Musgrave, you shall be my Guest,
My Dame, I trow, will welcome you herself.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: No Boy, Lord Lacy's wife shall welcome thee.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: So now the game begins, here is some Cheer toward;
I must be Skinker then, let me alone;
They all shall want ere Robin shall have none.

div2.stage: Exeunt all but Clin. and Harv.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Sirrah, Ralph Harvey, now the entry is made,
Thou only hast access without suspect,
Be not forgetful of thy Agent here,
Remember Clinton was the man that did it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Why Captain, now you talk in jealousy.
Do not misconster my true meaning heart

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.l: Ralph, I believe thee, and rely on thee,
Do not too long absent thee from the Doctor;
Go in, carouse, and taint his Spanish brain,
I will follow and my Marian's health maintain.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Captain, you well advise me, I will go in,
And for myself, my love-suites I will begin.

div1.head: ACT III.
div1.stage: Enter Rob. Goodfellow with his head broken

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: The Devil himself take all such Dames for me
'Swounds, I had rather be in hell than here;
Nay let him be his own man if he list,
Robin means not to stay to be used thus,
The very first day in her angry spleen,
Her nimble hand began to greet my Ears
With such unkind salutes as I never felt;
And since that time there hath not past an hour
Wherein she hath not either railed upon me,
Or laid her anger's load upon my limbs;
Even now for no occasion in the world,
But as it pleased her Ladyship to take it,
She gate me up a staff and breaks my head;
But I will no longer serve so cursed a Dame,
I will run as far first as my legs will bear me:
What shall I do? to Hell I dare not go!
Until my Master's Twelve months be expired.
And here to stay with Mistress Marian,
Better to be so long in purgatory.
Now farewell Master, but shrewd Dame fare ill
I will leave you, though the Devil is with you still.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My heart still pants within; I am so chafed,
The Rascal slave my man, that sneaking Rogue
Had like to have undone us all forever;
My Cozen Musgrave is with Honorea,
Set in an Arbour in the Summer Garden,
And he, forsooth, must needs go in for herbs,
And told me further, that his Master bid him;
But I laid hold upon my Yonker's pate,
And made the blood run down about his ears,
I trow he shall ask me leave ere he go;
Now is my Cozen Master of his Love,
The Lady at one time revenged and pleased:
So speed they all that marry Maids perforce;
But here my Husband comes.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What Dame alone?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes Sir, this once for want of company.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Why, where is my Lady, and my Cozen Musgrave?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You may go look them both for aught I know.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What, are you angry Dame?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yea, so it seems.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What is the cause I prithee?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why would you know?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: That I might ease it, if it lay in me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O, but it belongs not to your trade.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: You know not that.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I know you love to prate, and so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Well, go thy way; oft have I raked hell
To get a wife, yet never found her like:
Why this it is to marry with a Shrew.
Yet, if it be, as I presume it is,
There is but one thing offends both her and me,
And I am glad if that be it offends her.
It is so no doubt, I read it in her brow,
Lord Lacy shall, with all my heart, enjoy
Fair Honorea, Marian is mine;
Who though she be a Shrew, yet is she honest;
So is not Honorea, for even now,
Walking within my Garden all alone,
She came with Musgrave, stealing closely by,
And follows him that seeks to fly from her;
I spied this all unseen, and left them there;
But sure my Dame hath some conceit thereof,
And therefore she is thus angry, honest Soul:
Well, I will straight hence unto my Lord of Kent,
And warn him watch his wife from these close meetings.
Well Marian, thou livest yet free from blame,
Let Ladies go, thou art the Devil's Dame.

div1.stage: Enter the Devil like Musgrave with Honorea.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: No Lady, let thy modest virtuous life
Be always joined with thy comely shape,
For Lust eclipseth Nature's ornament.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Young heady Boy, thinkst thou thou shalt recall
Thy long made Love, which thou so oft hast sworn?
Making my Maiden-thoughts to dote on thee.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: With patience hear me, and if what I say
Shall jump with reason, then you will pardon me:
The time hath been when my Soul's liberty
Vowed servitude unto that heavenly face,
Whilst both had equal liberty of choice:
But since the holy bond of marriage
Hath left me single, you a wedded wife,
Let me not be the third, unlawfully
To do Earl Lacy so foul Injury;
But now at last,

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I would that last
Might be thy last, thou Monster of all men.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: Hear me with patience.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Cease, I will hear no more;
It is my Affection, and not Reason speaks;
Thou Musgrave turn the hardness of thy heart,
And now at last incline thy love to mine.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Nay now I see thou wilt not be reclaimed,
Go and bestow this hot love on the Earl,
Let not these loose affects, thus scandalise
Your fair report; go home and learn to live
As chaste as Lucrece, Madam so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O stay a little while, and hear my tongue
Speak my hearts words, which cannot choose but tell thee,
I hate the Earl, only because I love thee.
Disdain hath left him wings to fly from me,
Sweet Love lend me thy wings to overtake him,
For I can stay him with kind dalliance!
All this is but the blindness of my fancy.
Recall thyself: let not thy honour bleed
With the foul wounds of Infamy and Shame:
My proper Home shall call me home again,
Where my dear Lord bewails as much as I,
His too much love to her that loves not him.
Let none hereafter fix her maiden love
Too firm on any, lest she feel with me,
Musgrave's revolt, and his unconstancy.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Tut, I will remember thee, and straight return,
But here is the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Where? Forrest, farewell,
I would not have him see me for a world.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Why? he is not here, well now I see you fear him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Marry beshrew thee for thy false alarum,
I fear him? no, I neither fear nor love him.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: But where is my Lady, she is gone home before,
And I must follow after, Marian farewell.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall expect your coming.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Presently, and hearest thou Marian, nay it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Lord, sir, you are wed I warrant you,
We will laugh, be merry, and it may be kiss,
But if you look for more, you aim amiss.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Go to, go to, we will talk of this anon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well go thy way, for the true-heartedest man
That livest, and as full of honesty,
And yet as wanton as a pretty Lamb;
He will come again, for he hath loved me long,
And so have many more besides himself:
But I was coy and proud, as Maids are wont,
Meaning to match beyond my mean estate,
Yet have I favoured youths, and youthful sports,
Although I durst not venture on the main;
But now it will not be so soon espied.
Maids cannot, but a wife a fault may hide.
What Nan!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Anon forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come hither Maid,
Here take my keys, and fetch the galley pot,
Bring a fair Napkin, and some fruit dishes,
Dispatch and make all ready presently,
Miles Forrest will come straight to drink with me.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: I will forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why am I young, but to enjoy my years?
Why am I fair, but that I should be loved?
And why should I be loved, and not love others?
Tut, she is a fool, that her affection smothers:
It was not for love I was the Doctor's wife,
Nor did he love me when he first was mine;
Tush, tush, this Wife is but an idle name,
I purpose now to try another Game.
Art thou returned so soon! O it is well done.
And hearest thou Nan, when Forrest shall return,
If any happen to enquire for me,
Whether it be Captain Clinton, or Ralph Harvey,
Call presently, and say thy Master is come,
So I will send Forrest over the Garden pale.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: I will forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mean time stay thou and make our banquet ready,
I will to my Closet, and be here again,
Before Miles Forrest shall come visit me.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: I wonder what my Mistress is about,
Somewhat she would not have my Master know;
Whatever it be, it is nothing unto me,
She is my good Mistress, and I will keep her Counsel,
I have oft seen her kiss behind his back,
And laugh and toy when he did little think it:
O what a winking eye the Wanton hath
To cozen him, even when he looks upon her.
But what have I to do with what she doth?
I will taste her Junkets, since I am alone,
That which is good for them, cannot hurt me,
Aye marry this is sweet, a cup of Wine
Will not be hurtful for digestion.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I would I had been wiser once today,
I went on purpose to my Lord of Kent,
To give him some good counsel for his Wife,
And he, poor Heart, no sooner heard my news,
But turns me up his Whites, and falls flat down;
There I was fain to rub and chafe his veins,
And much ado we had to get him live;
But for all that he is extremely sick,
And I am come in all the haste I may
For Cordials to keep the Earl alive:
But how now, what a Banquet what means this?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Alas my Master is come home himself:
Mistress, Mistress, my Master is come home,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Peace you young Strumpet, or I will stop your speech:
Come hither Maid, tell me, and tell me true,
What means this Banquet? what is your Mistress doing?
Why camest thou out, when as thou sawest me coming?
Tell me, or else I will hang thee by the heels,
And whip thee naked: come on, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Forsooth I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Can you not tell: come on, I will make you tell me.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: O Master! I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Then say on.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Nothing in truth forsooth but that she means
To have a Gentleman come drink with her.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Forsooth it is Master. Forrest as I think.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Forrest! nay then I know how the Game goeth,
Whoever looseth I am sure to win
By their great kindness, though it be but the Horns:
sp.stage: Enter Forrest at one door, Marian at another.
sp.l: But here comes he and she, come hither Maid,
Upon thy life give not a word, a look,
That she may know aught of my being here;
Stand still, and do whatever she bids thee do.
Go, get thee gone, but if thou dost betray me,
I will cut thy Throat, look to it, for I will do it;
I will stand here close to see the end of this,
And see what Reaks she keeps when I am abroad.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is kindly done Miles to return so soon,
And so I take it. Nan, is our Banquet ready?
Welcome my Love, I see you will keep your word.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: It were better for ye both he had not kept it.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Yea Mariana, else I were unworthy,
I did but bring my Lady to the door,
And there I left her full of melancholy,
And discontented.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, it was kindly done,
Come, come sit down, and let us laugh a while.
Maid, fill some Wine

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Alas my Breech makes Buttons,
And so would theirs, knew they as much as I.
He may change the sweet meats, and put
Purging comfits in the Dishes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here is to my Lady, and my Cozen Musgrave.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: I pray remember gentle Master Doctor,
And good Earl Lacy too among the rest.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O sir, we find you kind, we thank you for it,
The time may come when we may cry you quit,

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Master, shall I steal you a cup of wine?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Away you Baggage, hold your peace you Wretch.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: But I had rather walk into your Orchard,
And see your Gallery so much commended,
To view the Workmanship he brought from Spain,
Wherein is described the banquet of the gods.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Aye, there is one piece exceeding lively done,
Where Mars and Venus lie within a net,
Enclosed by Vulcan, and he looking on.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Better and better yet, it will mend anon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Another of Diana with her Nymphs,
Bathing their naked bodies in the streams,
Where fond Acteon, for his eyes offence,
Is turned into a Hart's shape, horns and all;
And this the Doctor hangs right over his bed.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Those Horns may fall and light upon his head.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: And if they do, worse Luck, what remedy?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Nay Marian, we will not leave these sights unseen,
And then we will see your Orchard and your fruit;
For now there hangs Queen apples on the trees,
And one of them are worth a score of these.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well, you shall see them, lest you loose your longing.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Nay, if ye fall a-longing for green fruit,
Childbearing is not far off I am sure:
Why this is excellent, I feel the buds,
My Head groweth hard, my Horns will shortly spring,
Now who may lead the Cuckold's dance but I?
That am become the head man of the Parish:
O! this it is to have an honest wife,
Of whom so much I boasted once today.
Come hither Minks, you know your Mistress's mind,
And you keep secret all her villainies,
Tell me, you were best, where was this Plot devised?
How did these Villains know I was abroad?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Indeed forsooth I knew not when it was,
My Mistress called me from my work of late,
And bad me lay a Napkin; so I did,
And made this Banquet ready: but in truth
I knew not what she did intend to do.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No, no, you did not watch against I came,
To give her warning to dispatch her Knaves?
You cried not out, when as you saw me come,
All this is nothing but I will rouse you all.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: In truth good Master.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Peace I say, they come.
Whimper not, if you do, I will use you worse:
Behold that wicked Strumpet with that Knave,
O that I had a pistol for their sakes,
That at one shot I might dispatch them both:
But I must stand close yet, and see the rest.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How likest thou Miles my Orchard, and my House.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Well, thou art seated to thy hearts content,
A pleasant Orchard, and a House well furnished,
There nothing wants; but in the Gallery
The Painter shows his art exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yet is there one thing goeth beyond all these,
Contented life, that giveth the Heart his ease.
And that I want.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Sweet Love, adieu.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Farewell Sweetheart. Who is that at the door?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: A Friend.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come near. What Captain is it you?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Even I, fair Marian watching carefully
The blessed step of opportunity.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good, good! how Fortune gluts me with excess!
Still they that have enough shall meet with more.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: But where is the Doctor?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ministering abroad
Physic to some sick Patients he retains.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Let him abroad, I will minister at home,
Such Physic shall content my Marian.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O monstrous! now the World must see my shame,
This Head must bear whatever likes my Dame.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have no malady requires recure.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Why, then must I assume a sick man's part,
And all my sickness lieth at my heart,
It is the heart-burning that torments me so.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: There is no cure for fire but to be quenched.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Thou hast prescribed a sovereign remedy.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O who the Devil made her a Physician?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Let us not obscure what Love doth manifest,
Nor let a Stranger's bed make thee seem strange
To him that ever loved and honoured thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A Captain made a Captive by loose Love,
And gadding Fancy; fie, it were monstrous shame
That Cupid's bow should blemish Mars his name;
Take up thy Arms, recall thy drooping thoughts,
And lead thy Troops into the spacious Fields.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: She counsels others well, if she would take it.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Thou counsellest the blind to lead the blind;
Can I lead them that cannot guide myself?
Thou, Marian, must release my captive Heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: With all my heart, I grant thee free release.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Thou art obscure too much: but tell me, Love,
Shall I obtain my long-desired Love?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Captain, there is yet somewhat in thy mind
Thou wouldst reveal, but wantest utterance;
Thou better knowest to front the braving foe,
Than plead Love suites.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: I grant it is even so,
Extremity of Passions still are dumb,
No tongue can tell Love's chief perfections,
Persuade thyself my Love-sick thoughts are thine,
Thou only mayst those drooping thoughts refine.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Since at my hands thou seekst a remedy,
I will ease thy grief, and cure thy malady;
No drug the Doctor hath shall be too dear,
His antidote shall fly to do thee good,
Come in and let thy eye make choice for thee,
That thou mayst know how dear thou art to me.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Is this obedience, now the Devil go with them,
And yet I dare not; O she is mankind grown!
O miserable men that must live so,
And damned Strumpets, Authors of this woe:
But peace! be still! they come! O shameless shame,
Well may the world call thee the Devil's dame.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Captain thy skill hath pleased me so well,
That I have vowed my service to Bellona.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Her service to Bellona! turned stark Ruffian!
She will be called Cavaliero Marian.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: And I will train thee up in feats of arms,
And teach thee all the orders of the field,
That whilst we, like to Mars and Venus, jest,
The Doctor's head may get a gallant crest.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I can no longer linger my disgrace,
Nor hide my shame from their detested sight,
How now thou Whore, dishonour to my bed,
Disdain to Womanhood, shame of thy sex,
Insatiate monster, corsive of my Soul,
What makes this Captain revelling in my house?
My House! nay, in my Bed! you will prove a Soldier,
Follow Bellona, turn a Martialist!
I will try if thou hast learnt to ward my blows.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why how now man! is this your madding month?
What, sir, will you forbid me in good sort,
To entertain my friends.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Your Friends, you Whore:
They are no Friends of mine, nor come they here:
Clinton avaunt, my House is for no such.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas good sir, are you grown so suspicious,
Thus on no proofs to nourish jealousy;
I cannot kiss a man, but you will be angry.
In spite of you, or whoso else sayeth nay,
My Friends are welcome as they come this way,
If thou mislike it, mend it as thou may:
What do you think to pin up Marian,
As you were wont to do your Spanish girls,
No sir, I will be half Mistress of myself,
The other half is yours, if you deserve it.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: What madness moved thee be displeased with me,
That always used thee with so kind regard,
Did I not at thy first arrival here
Conduct thee to the Earl of London's house?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Did I not, being unsolicited,
Bestow my first pure Maiden-love on thee?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Did I not grace the there in all the Court,
And bear thee out against the daring Abbot?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Did I forsake many young Gallant Courtiers,
Enamoured with thy aged Gravity?
Who now being weary of me, wouldst disgrace me?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: If there be any Conscience left on earth,
How can I but believe these Protestations?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Have I not always been thy nearest friend?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have I not always been thy dearest wife?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: How much will all the world in this condemn thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: At first I little feared what now I find,
And grieve too late.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Content thee gentle Dame,
The nature of our Countrymen is such,
That if we see another kiss our Wives,
We cannot brook it: but I will be pleased;
For, will I, nill I, so methinks I must:
And gentle Captain, be not you offended,
I was too hot at first, but now repent it:
I prithee gentle Dame forgive me this,
And drown all Jealousy in this sweet kiss.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: This shows your wisdom; on, I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well Doctor, henceforth never reck it scorn,
At my sweet Clinton's hands to take the horn.

div1.head: ACT. IV.
div1.stage: Enter Robin Good fellow in a suite of Leather close to his body, his Face and Hands coloured russet-colour, with a Flayle.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: The Doctor's self would scarce know Robin now:
Cursed Marian may go seek another man,
For I intend to dwell no longer with her,
Since that the Bastinado drove me thence;
These silken Girls are all too fine for me,
My Master shall report of those in Hell,
Whilst I go range amongst the Country maids,
To see if home-spun Lasses milder be
Than my cursed Dame, and Lacie's wanton wife;
Thus therefore will I live betwixt two shapes,
When as I list in this transformed disguise,
I will fright the Country people as they pass,
And sometimes turn me to some other form,
And so delude them with fantastic shows:
But woe betide the silly Dairy maids,
For I shall fleet their Cream-bowls night by night.
And slice the Bacon filches as they hang.
Well here in Croydon will I first begin
To frolic it among the Country Lobs:
This day they say is called Holy-rood day,
And all the Youth are now a-nutting gone;
Here are a crew of Yonkers in this Wood,
Well sorted, for each Lad hath got his Lass;
Marry indeed there is a tricksy Girl,
That three or four would fain be doing with,
But that a wily Priest among the rest,
Intends to bear her share away from all;
The Miller, and my Brother Grim the Collier,
Appointed here to scuffle for her Love:
I am on Grim's side, for long time ago
The Devil called the Collier like to like:
sp.stage: Enter Grim, Clack, Parson Shorthose. Ione with a bagg of Nutts.
sp.l: But here the Miller and the Collier come,
With Parson Make bate, and their tricksy Girl.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Parson, persuade me no more, I come
Jug to your custody, Jug hold the Nut-bag.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.l: Nay, I will give you Nuts to crack.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Crack in thy Throat and hauster too.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Neighbours I wish you both agree,
Let me be judge, be ruled by me.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Master. Parson, remember what Pluriles saith, ne aceesseris ad consilio, etcetera; I tell you I found this written in the bottom of one of my empty Sacks; never persuade men that be inexecrable: I have vowed it, and I will perform it: the Quarrel is great, and I have taken it upon my own Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.l: Aye that thou shalt ere I have done, for I will lay it on i'faith.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: If you lay it in, I must bear it out: this is all: If you strike, I must stand to anything although it be the biggest blow that you can lay upon me.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Ye both have oftentimes sworn that ye love me,
Let me over-rule you in this angry mood:
Neighbours and old acquaintance, and fall out!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why, that is because thou wilt not let them fall in?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I say, my heart bleedeth when thou speakest, and therefore do not provoke me: yet Miller, as I am monstrous angry, so I have a wonderful great mind to be repeasedspyal: let us think what harm cometh by this same fighting, if we should hurt one another, how can we help it? Again, Clack do but here forswear Ione's company, and I will be thine instead of hers, to use in all your businesses from Croydon to London, yours Gilbert Grim, the chief Collier for the King's Majesties own mouth.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.p: O Grim, do I smell you? I will make you forswear her before we two part, and therefore come on to this gear: Collier I will lay on load, and when it is done, let who will take it off again.

sp.speaker: Iugg.
sp.l: Yet once more hear me speak, leave off for shame,
If not for Love, and let not others laugh
To see your follies, let me overrule ye.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: O let them fight, I care not, I,
Mean time away with Ione I will fly,
And whilst they two are at it here,
We two will sport ourselves elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: There is a stone Priest, he loveth a Wench indeed,
He careth not though both of them do bleed;
But Robin Goodfellow will conjure you,
And mar your match, and bang you soundly too;
I like this Country Girl's condition well,
She is faithful, and a Lover but to one,
Robin stands here to right both Grim and her.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Master Parson, look you to my Love; Miller, here I stand with my Heart and my Hand in sweet Jug is right, with thee to fight.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.l: Come let us to it then.

div1.stage: They fight, Robin beateth the Miller with a Flayle, and felleth him.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now Miller, Miller, dustipoule,
I will clapper-claw your Iobbernoule.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Come Jug, let us leave these senseless Blocks,
Giving each other blows and knocks.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: I love my Grim too well to leave him so.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: You shall not choose, come let us away.

div1.stage: Shorthose pulleth Jugg after him, Robin beateth the Priest with his Flayle.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay then Sir Priest I will make you stay.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.p:
Nay this is nothing Grim, we will not part
I thought to have borne it off with my back-sword ward, and I received it upon my bare Costard.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What Miller are you up again!
Nay then my Flail shall never lin,
Until I force one of us twain,
Betake him to his heels amain.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.l: Hold thy hands Grim, thou hast murdered me.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Thou liest, it is in my own offence I do it; get thee gone then; I had rather have thy room than thy company.

sp.speaker: Clack.
sp.l: Marry with all my heart; O! the Collier playeth the Devil with me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: No, it is the Devil playeth the Collier with thee.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: My bones are sore, I prithee Ione,
Let us quickly from this place be gone,
Nay come away, I love thee so,
Without thee I will never go.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What Priest still at your Lechery,
I will thresh you for your Knavery;
If any ask who beat thee so,
Tell them it was Robin Goodfellow.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: O Miller art thou gone, I am glad of it; I smell my own infirmity every stroke I struck at him: now Ione I dare boldly swear thou art my own, for I have won thee in the plain field; now Master Parson shall even strike it up; two or three words of his mouth will make her Gammer Grim all the days of her life after.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Here is two well-favoured Slaves, Grim and I may curse all good faces,
And not hurt our own.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: What, my Love, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Even as a Conqueror may do; Jug, for thy sake I have made the Miller a poor Cripple all days of his life; good for nothing else but to be carried into the Spittle-house.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Aye, there is one lie, for thou didst never hurt him.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: I am glad thou scapest my love, and wast not hurt,

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Who, I hurt! Ione, thou knowest me not yet, thou mayst do better hereafter, I gave him five mortal wounds, the first five strokes I made at him.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: There are five lies clapped into one for brevity sake.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: And presently upon the fifth blow I made a dangerous thrust at him, and violently overthrew him horse and foot, and there he lay.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay, there you lie, the Collier is excellent
To be Companion to the Devil himself.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: But where is Master Parson?

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: He was well banged, and knew not who it was did it,
And would have had me gone away with him:
Here lieth his Nut-bag, and the Millers too,
They had no leisure to take them away.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p:
The better for us Ione, there is good cracking work, it Will increase Household-stuff: Come, let us after the Parson, we will comfort him, and he shall couple us: I will have Pounceby the Painter score upon our painted Cloth at home all the whole story of our going a-nutting this Holy-rood day, and he shall paint me up triumphing
over the Miller.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: So let the Collier now go boast at home
How he hath beat the Miller from his Love;
I like this modest Country maid so well,
That I believe I must report in hell
Better of women than my Master can:
Well, till my time is expired, I will keep this Quarter,
And night by night attend their merry meetings.

div1.stage: Enter Dunston with Earle Lacy sick.

sp.speaker: Dunston.
sp.l: Let not your sickness add more feebleness
Unto your weakened age, but give me leave
To cure thy vain suspicious malady,
Thy eyes shall witness how thou art deceived,
