Misprising thy fair Ladies chastity;
For whilst we two stand closely here unseen,
We shall espy them presently approach.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: O show me this thou blessed man of God,
And thou shalt then make young my withered Age.

sp.speaker: Dunston.
sp.l: Mark the beginning, for here Musgrave cometh.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: O thrice unhappy and unfortunate,
That having fit occasion proffered thee
Of conference with beauteous Honorea,
Thou over-slipped it, and over-slipst thyself,
Never since Wedlock tied her to the Earl.
Have I saluted her, although report
Is blazed abroad of my unconstancy,
This is her evening walk, and here will I
Attend her coming forth, and greet her fairly

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: See Dunston how their youth doth blind our Age,
Thou dost deceive thyself, and bringest me
To see my proper shame and infamy.
But here she comes, my hope, my fear, my love,

sp.speaker: Dunst.
sp.l: Here comes the unstained honour of thy Bed,
Thy Ears shall hear her virtuous chaste replies,
And make thy heart confess thou dost her wrong.

sp.speaker: Honorea.
sp.l: Now modest love hath banished wanton thoughts,
And altered me from that I was before:
To that chaste life I ought to entertain,
My heart is tied to that strict form of life,
That I joy only to be Lacy's wife.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: God fill thy mind with these chaste virtuous thoughts.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: O now I see her, I am half ashamed,
Of so long absence and neglect of speech;
My dearest Lady, Patroness of Beauty,
Let thy poor Servant make his true excuse.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Musgrave, I easily take your excuse,
Accusing my fond self for what is past.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: Long time we wanted opportunity;
But now the forelock of well wishing time,
Hath blessed us both, that here without suspect
We may renew the tenor of our loves.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: O Dunston how she smiles to hear him speak!

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: No Child of fortune and inconstancy,
Thou shalt not train me, or induce my love
To loose desires, or dishonoured thoughts,
It is God's own work that struck a deep remorse
Into my tainted heart for my past folly.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: O thou confoundest me, speak as thou wert wont,
Like Love herself, my lovely Honorea.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Why, how now Musgrave, what esteemest thou me!
That thou provokest me, that first deniedest me:
I will not yield you reasons why I may not,
More than your own, you told me why, you would not.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: By Heavens, by thee my Saint, my Happiness,
No torture shall control my heart in this,
To teach my tongue deny to call thee Love.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Well in regard that in my maiden-days
I loved thee well, now let me counsel thee,
Reclaim these idle humours; know thyself;
Remember me; and think upon my Lord;
And let these thoughts bring forth those chaste effects,
Which may declare thy change unto the world;
And this assure thee, whilst I breath this air,
Earl Lacy's honour I will never impair.

sp.speaker: Dunst.
sp.l: Now your Eyes see that which your Heart believed not.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: It is a miracle beyond the reach
Of my capacity, I could weep for joy,
Would but my tears express how much I love her,
Men may surmise amiss in jealousy,
Of those that live in untouched honesty.

sp.speaker: Musg.
sp.l: Is she departed, and do I conceive
This height of grief and do no violence
Unto myself, said she, I denied her;
Far be it from my heart to think that thought:
All ye that, as I do, have felt this smart,
Ye know how burdensome it is at my heart:
Hereafter never will I prosecute
This former motion, my unlawful suite:
But since she is Earl Lacy's virtuous wife,
I will live a private pensive single life.

sp.speaker: Dunst.
sp.l: God doth dispose all at his blessed will,
And he hath changed their minds from bad to good,
That we which see it may learn to mend ourselves.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: I will reconcile myself to Musgrave's love,
I will recant my false suspicion,
And humbly make my true submission.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sayst thou thou wilt make the House too hot for me.
I will soon abroad and cool me in the air.
I will teach him never scorn to drink his health
Whom I do love, he thinks to overcrow me
With words and blows, but he is in the wrong,
Begin he when he dares: O he is too hot
And angry to live long with Marian:
But I will not long be subject to his rage,
Here it is shall rid him of his hateful life,
And bless me with the style of Widow hood;
It was Harvey's work to temper it so well,
The strongest poison that he could devise,
I have been too long subject to the Slave.
But now I will cast off that detested yoke.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Musgrave I see is reconciled to the Earl,
For now I met him walking with Lord Lacy;
Sure this is Marian's Plot, and there she stands.
What Love alone!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Aye Captain, much disturbed
About the frantic Doctor's jealousy,
Who, though he seemed content when thou wast there,
He after fell reviling thee and me,
Robbed me of all my Jewels, locks his Plate
In his own Trunk, and lets me only live
To bear the idle Title of his Wife.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Fair Marian, by a Soldier's loyal faith,
If my employment any way may help
To set thee free from this Captivity,
Use me in any sort, command my Sword,
I will do it as soon as thou shalt speak the word.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now by my true Love, which I wish to thee,
I conjure thee with resolution
To slay that Monster, do not fail to do it,
For if thou dost, I would I had not spoke it.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Now try me, and when next we hap to meet,
The Doctor lies stone dead at Clinton's feet,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay now I see thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Say no more;
If thou dost loath him, he shall dye therefore.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tomorrow morning will he early rise
To see Earl Lacy, meet him in the Cloister,
And make that place revenge his Sanctuary:
This night will I break open all the Trunks,
Rifle his Caskets, rob him of his Gold;
And all the Doctors treasure shall be thine,
If thou miscarry, yet this drink shall do it.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: My wife's impatience hath left me alone,
And made my Servant run I know not whither.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Peace! here is our eye sore, Clinton leave us now.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Nay now occasion smiles, and I will do it.
Clinton draweth his Sword.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Put up thy Sword, be it thy mornings work;
Farewell tonight, but fail me not tomorrow

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Farewell my Love, no rest shall close these eyes;
Until the morning peep, and then he dies.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Now I remember I have quite out-run
My time prefixed to dwell upon the earth;
Yet Akercock is absent, where is he:
O I am glad I am so well near rid
Of my Earth's plague, and my lascivious dame.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hath he discovered my intendment,
That he presageth his ensuing death?
I must break off these fearful meditations.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: How shall I give my verdict up to Pluto
Of all these Accidents?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, how now man!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What my dear Dame, my reconciled Spouse!
Upon my Soul, my love to thee is more
Now at this present, than it was ever before.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He hath descried me sure, he sootheth me so.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I love thee now, because I now must leave thee;
This was the day of my Nativity,
And therefore Sweet wife let us revel it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, I have little cause to joy at all.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Thou crossest still my Mirth with discontents,
If ever heretofore I have displeased thee,
Sweet Dame, I crave thy pardon now for all;
This is my birthday, Girl, I must rejoice,
Ask what thou wilt, and I will give it thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Should I but ask to lead a quiet life,
You hardly would grant this unto your wife,
Much less a thing that were of more import.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Ask anything, and try if I will deny thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O my poor Musgrave, how hast thou been wronged,
And my fair Lady!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Use no Preambles,
But tell me plainly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay remember them,
And join their slander to that love you owe me,
And then old Lacye's jealousy

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay now I see you will not understand me.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Thou art too dark, speak plainly, and it is done.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then doom the Earl, and bless poor Musgrave's eyes
With Honorea's love; for this in thy Hand's lies.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: How should I doom him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How else, but to death?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: As if his life or death lay in my hands.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He is thy Patient, is he not?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: He is.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then in thy hands lies both his life and death,
Sweet Love, let Marian beg it at thy hands;
Why should the gray beard live to cross us all?
Nay now I see thee frown; thou wilt not do it.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Fie, fie, Dame, you are too suspicious.
Here is my hand, that thou mayst know I love thee,
I will poison him this night before I sleep.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou dost but flatter me!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Tush, I have sworn it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And wilt thou do it?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: He is sure to dye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will kiss thy Lips for speaking that kind word;
But do it, and I will hang about thy neck,
And curl thy hair, and sleep betwixt thy arms,
And teach thee pleasures which thou never knewest.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Promise no more, and trouble me no more,
The longer I stay here, he lives the longer;
I must go to him now, and now I will do it:
Go home, and hasten supper against I come,
We will carouse to his departing Soul.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will dear Husband, but I remember me;
When thou hast poisoned him, I will poison thee.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O wonderful how women can dissemble,
Now she can kiss me, hang about my neck,
And sooth me with smooth smiles and loud entreaties:
Well, I have promised her to kill the Earl,
And yet, I hope, ye will not think I will do it,
Yet I will sound the depth of their device,
And see the issue of their bloody drift,
I will give the Earl, unknown to any man,
A sleepy potion, which shall make him seem
As if he were stark dead, for certain hours:
But in my absence no man shall report,
That for my Dame's sake I did any hurt.

div1.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Nay but Ione, have a care, bear a brain for all at once, it is not one hours pleasure that I suspect, more than your Mother's good countenance; if she be asleep, we may be bold under correction, if she be awake, I may go my ways, and nobody ask me, Grim whither goest thou: nay I tell you I am so well beloved in our Town, that not the worst dog in the street will hurt my little finger.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Why speak you this, you need not fear my Mother,
For she was fast asleep four hours ago.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Is she sure, did you hear her snort in her dead sleep; why then Ione I have an hours mirth for thee.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: And I a mess of Cream for thee.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Why there is one for another then, fetch it Ione, we will eat and kiss, and be as merry

as your Cricket; art thou gone for for it: well, go thy ways for the kindest Lass that ever poor Collier met withal; I mean for to make short work with her, and marry her presently; I will single her out i'faith, till I make her beat double, and give the world to understand we will have a young Grim between us.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Look here my Love, it is sweetened for thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: You have put none of your Love powder in it to make me enamourable of you, have you Ione, I have a simple pate to expect you.
Ione hark, my Brains beat, my head works, and my mind giveth me, some Lovers of yours come sneaking hither now, I like it not, it is suspicious.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: You need not fear it, for there is none alive
Shall bear the least part of my heart from thee.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Sayst thou so, hold there still, and whoever he be, open door to him.

div1.stage: She openeth the door, enter Shorthose and Robin after him.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: what, Master Parson! are you come so late;
You are welcome, here is none but Grim and I.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Ione, I will no more a-nutting go,
I was so beaten to and fro;
And yet who it was I do not know.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: What, Master Parson, are you come so late to say evening song to your Parishioners, I have heard of your Knavery, I give you a fair warning, touch her no lower than her Girdle, and no higher than her chin; I keep her lips and her hips for my own use; I do, and so welcome.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: This two hours have I dogged the Parson round
About all Croydon, doubting some such thing.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: No Grim, I here forswear to touch
Thy Ione, or any other such;
Love hath been so cudgelled out of me,
I will go no more to wood with thee.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: It was Robin beat this holy mind into him,
I think more cudgelling would make him more honest.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: You speak like an honest man, and a good Parson, and that is more; here is Ione's benevolation for us, a mess of Cream and so forth. Here is your place, Master Parson, stand on the tother side of the Table Ione, eat hard tonight that thou may marry us the better tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What is my Brother Grim so good a fellow?
I love a mess of Cream as well as they;
I think it were best I stepped in and made one:
Ho, ho, ho my Masters, no good Fellowship!
Is Robin Goodfellow a Bug-bear grown.
That he is not worthy to be bid sit down.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: O Lord save us! sure he is some Country-devil, he hath got a Russet-coat upon his face.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Now benedicite! who is this?
I take him for some fiend Iwis,
O for some holy-water here
Of this same place this Sprite to clear.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay fear not Grim, come fall unto your Cream,
Tut, I am thy Friend, why dost not come and eat?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Aye Sir, truly, Master Devil, I am well here, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I will have thee come, I say, Why tremblest thou?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: No Sir, not I, it is a Palsy I have still:
Truly, Sir, I have no great acquaintance with you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Thou shalt have better man ere I depart.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I will not, and if I can choose.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay come away, and bring your Love with you.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Ione, you were best go to him Ione.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What shall I fetch the man? the Cream is sweet.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: No, Sir I am coming; much good do it you: I had need of a long spoon now I go to eat with the Devil.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: The Parson's penance shall be thus to fast:
Come tell me Grim, doest thou not know me man?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: No truly Sir, I am a poor man, fetcheth my Living out of the fire; your Worship may be a Gentleman Devil for aught I know.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Some men call me Robin Goodfellow.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: O Lord! Sir, Master. Robert Goodfellow, you are very welcome, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: This half year have I lived about this Town,
Helping poor Servants to dispatch their work,
To brew and bake, and other Husbandry;
Tut, fear not Maid, if Grim be merry,
I will make up the Match between ye.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: There will be a Match in the Devil's name!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Well now the night is almost spent,
Since your affections all are bent
To Marriage, and to constant Love,
Grim, Robin doth thy Choice approve,
And there is the Priest shall marry you;
Go to it, and make no mote ado:
Sirrah, Sir Priest, go get you gone,
And join both her and him anon;
But never hereafter let me take you
With wanton Love-tricks, lest I make you
Example to all stone-priests ever,
To deal with other men's loves never.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: Valete vos, and God bless me,
And rid me from his Company.
Come Grim I will join you hand in hand,
In sacred Wedlock's holy band;
I will no more a-nutting go,
That journey caused all this woe.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Come, let us to hand in hand quickly, Master Robert you were ever one of the honestest merry Devils that ever I saw.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Sweet Grim, and if thou lovest me let us away.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Nay, now Ione, I spy a hole in your coat, if you cannot endure the Devil, you will never love the Collier, why we two are sworn Brothers, you shall see me talk with him even as familiarly as if I should parbreak my mind and my whole stomach upon thee.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: I prithee do not Grim.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Who, not I? O Lord! Master. Robert Goodfellow, I have a poor Cottage at home, whither Ione and I will jog as merrily; we will make you no Stranger if you come thither, you shall be used as devilishly as you would wish i'faith; there is never a time my Cart cometh from London, but the Collier bringeth a Goose in his Sack and that, with the Giblets thereof, is at your service.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: This is more kindness Grim than I expected.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, if you come home, you shall find it true I warrant you, all my whole Family shall be at your Devilships pleasure, except my poor Ione here, and she is my own proper night gear.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Gramercies, but away in haste,
The night is almost spent and past.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: God be with you, Sir, I will make as much haste about it as may be, for if that were once done, I would begin a new piece of work with you Ione.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now joy betide this merry morn,
And keep Grims forehead from the horn,
For Robin bids his last adieu,
To Grim and all the rest of you.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Bright Lucifer go cochu thee in the Clouds,
And let this morning prove as dark as night,
That I unseen may bring to happy end
The Doctor's murder, which I do intend:
It is early yet, he is not so soon stirring;
But stir he never so soon, so soon he dies;
I will walk along before the Palace gate;
Then shall I know how near it is to day,
He shall have no means to escape away.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: My Trunk is broke open, and my Jewels gone,
My Gold and Treasure stolen, my House despoiled
Of all my Furniture, and nothing left,
No not my Wife, for she is stolen away,
But she hath peppered me. I feel it work,
My Teeth are loose, and my Belly swelled,
My Entrails burn with such distempered heat,
That well I know my Dame hath poisoned me;
When she spoke fairest, then she did this Act.
When I have spoken all I can imagine,
I cannot utter half that she intends;
She makes as little poisoning of a man
As to carouse, I feel that this is true:
Nay now I know too much of Women kind,
'Swounds here is the Captain! what should he make here
With his Sword drawn? there is yet more Villainy.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: The morning is far spent, but yet he comes not!
I wonder Marian sends him not abroad!
Well Doctor, linger time and linger life,
For long thou shalt not breath upon the earth.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No, no, I will not live amongst ye long,
Is that for me thou waitest thou bloody Wretch?
Her Poison hath prevented thee in Murther.
sp.stage: Enter Earle Morgan, St. Dunston, with Honorea fainting, and Mariana.
sp.l: Now here be they suppose Earl Lacy dead,
See how his Lady grieveth for that she wisheth?

sp.speaker: Dunst.
sp.l: My Lord of London, by his sudden death,
And all the signs before his late departure,
It is very probable that he is poisoned.

sp.speaker: Marian.
sp.l: Do you but doubt it! credit me my Lord,
I heard him say, That drink should be his last,
I heard my Husband speak it, and he did it.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: There is my old Friend, she always speaks for me;
O shameless Creature! was it not thy devise?

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: Let not extremity of grief overwhelm thee,
My dearest Honorea, for his death shall be
Surely revenged with all severity
Upon the Doctor, and that suddenly.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: What Fortune is this, that all these come this way
To hinder me, and save thy life today.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, this doleful accident
Hath robbed me of my joy; And royal Earl,
Though in thy life thou didst suspect my love,
My grief and tears suspicions shall remove.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Madam to you and to your Father's love,
I owe as much and more than my own life,
Had I ten Husbands should agree to do it,
My gracious Lord you presently should know it.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Aye! there is a Girl: Think you I did not well
To live with such a Wife, to come from Hell.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Look, look, my Lord, there stands the Murderer.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: How am I round beset on every side!
First, that same Captain, here stands to kill me,
My Dame she hath already poisoned me,
Earl Morgan he doth threaten present death,
The Countess Honorea, in revenge
Of Lacy, is extremely incensed against me;
All threatens, none shall do it, for my date
Is now expired, and I must back to Hell.
And now my Servant wheresoever thou be,
Come quickly Akercock, and follow me;
Lordings adieu, and my cursed Wife farewell,
If me ye seek, come follow me to Hell.
The Ground opens, and he falls down into it.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: The Earth that opened, now is closed again!

sp.speaker: Dunst.
sp.l: It is God's judgment for his grievous sins.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Was there a Quagmire, that he sunk so soon?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O miracle! now may we justly say,
Heavens have revenged my Husband's death this day.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: Alas poor Marian! we have wronged thee much,
To cause thee march thyself to any such.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay let him go, and sink into the ground,
For such as he are better lost than found;
Now Honorea we are freed from blame,
And both enriched with happy Widows names.

div1.stage: Enter Earl Lacy with Forest, Musgrave.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: O lead me quickly to that mourning train,
Which weep for me, that am revived again.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Marian, I shed some tears of perfect grief.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: Do not my Eyes deceive me? liveth my Son?

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: My Lord, and Father, both alive and well
Recovered of my weakness: where is my wife?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here is my Lady, your beloved wife,
Half dead to hear of your untimely end.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Look on me Honorea; see thy Lord:
I am not dead, but live to love thee still.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.l: It is God disposeth all things as he will,
He raiseth those the wicked wish to fall.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: 'Swounds, I still watch on this enclosed ground;
For if he rise again, I will murder him.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: My Lord, my tongue is not able to report
Those joys my heart conceives to see thee live!

sp.speaker: Dunst.
sp.l: Give God the glory: he recovered thee,
And wrought this judgment on that cursed man,
That set debate and strife among ye all.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: My Lord, our eyes have seen a miracle,
Which after-ages ever shall admire,
The Spanish Doctor, standing here before us,
Is sunk into the bowels of the earth,
Ending his vile life by a viler death.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: But, gentle Marian, I bewail thy loss,
That wert Maid, Wife, and Widow, all so soon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is your recovery that joys me more
Than grief can touch me for the Doctor's death;
He never loved me whilst he lived with me,
Therefore the less I mourn his Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: Henceforth we will strictlier look to Strangers lives,
Now they shall marry any English Wives:
Now all men shall record this fatal day,
Lacy revived, the Doctor sunk in Clay.

div1.stage: The Trumpets sound, exeunt all but Dunstan.

sp.speaker: Dunst.
sp.l: Now is Earl Lacy's House filled full of joy,
He and his Lady wholly reconciled,
Their jars all ended; those that were like men
Transformed, turned unto their shapes again:
And Gentlemen, before we make an end,
A little longer yet your patience lend,
That in your friendly censures you may see
What the infernal Synod do decree,
And after judge, if we deserve to name
This Play of ours, The Devil and his Dame.

div1.stage: It thunders and lighteneth; enter Pluto, Minos, Aeacus, Rhadamanthus, with Furies bringing in Malbecco's ghost.

sp.speaker: Pluto.
sp.l: Minos, is this the day he should return
And bring us tidings of his Twelve month spent.

div1.stage: Enter Belphagor like a Devil, with Horns on his head, and Akerkok.

sp.speaker: Minos.
sp.l: It is, great King, and here Belphagon comes.

sp.speaker: Pluto.
sp.l: His Visage is more ghastly than it was wont.
What Ornaments are those upon his head?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hell, I salute thee, now I feel myself
Rid of a thousand torments; O vile Earth,
Worse for us Devils, than Hell itself for men!
Dread Pluto, hear thy Subject's just Complaint,
Proceeding from the anguish of my Soul,
O never send me more into the Earth,
For there dwells dread, and horror more than here.

sp.speaker: Pluto.
sp.l: Stand forth Belphagor, and report the truth
Of all things have betide thee in the World.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: When first, great King, I came into the Earth,
I chose a Wife both young and beautiful,
The only Daughter to a noble Earl:
But when the night came, that I should her bed,
I found another laid there in her stead,
And in the morning when I found the change,
Though I denied her, I was forced to take her;
With her I lived in such a mild estate,
Used her still kindly, loved her tenderly;
Which she requited with such light regard,
So loose demeanour, and dishonest life,
That she was each man's whore that was my wife:
No hours but Gallants flocked unto my house,
Such as she fancied for her loathsome lust,
With whom, before my face, she did not spare
To play the Strumpet; yea, and more than this,
She made my house a stew for all resorts,
Herself a Bawd to other's filthiness;
Which if I once began but to reprove,
O! then her Tongue was worse than all the rest,
No ears with patience would endure to hear her,
Nor would she ever cease till I submit,
And then she would speak me fair, but wish me dead:
A hundred drifts she laid to cut me off,
Still drawing me to dangers of my life;
And now my Twelve-month being near expired,
She poisoned me; and least that means should fail,
She enticed a Captain to have murdered me
In brief, whatever Tongue can tell,
All that may well be spoken of my Dame.

sp.speaker: Aker.
sp.l: Poor Akercock was fain to fly her sight,
For never an hour but she laid on me,
Her Tongue and Fist walked all so nimbly.

sp.speaker: Pluto.
sp.l: Doth then Belphagor this report of thine
Against all Women hold in general?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Not so, great Prince, for as amongst other Creatures,
Under that Sex are mingled good and bad,
There are some women virtuous, chaste and true,
And to all those the Devil will give their due:
But, O my Dame! born for a song to man,
For no mortality would endure that,
Which she a thousand times hath offered me.

sp.speaker: Pluto.
sp.l: But what new shapes are those upon thy Head?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: These are the ancient arms of Cuckoldry,
And these my Dame hath kindly left to me,
For which Belphagor shall be here derided,
Unless your great infernal Majesty
Do solemnly proclaim, no Devil shall scorn
Hereafter still to wear the goodly horn

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: This for thy service I will grant thee freely,
All Devils shall, as thou dost like horns wear,
And none shall scorn Belphagor's arms to bear;
And now Malbecco, bear thy latest doom,
Since that thy first Reports are justified
By after-proofs, and Women's looseness known,
One Plague more will I send upon the earth,
Thou shalt assume a light and fiery shape,
And so forever live within the world.
Dive into Women's thoughts, into men's hearts,
Raise up false rumours, and suspicious fears,
Put strange inventions into each man's mind;
And for these Actions they shall always call thee
By no name else but fearful Jealousy:
Go Jealousy, be gone, thou hast thy charge,
Go range about the World that is so large.
And now for joy Belphagor is returned,
The Furies shall their tortures east away,
And in Hell we will make it Holy-day.

div1.stage: It thundereth and lighteneth; exeunt omnes.
